body:
To be honest I feel like this "context" example is a ruse to get innocent
people to want and fight for aliases. The harm to be done is not worth the
gain in my opinion.

On Saturday, July 30, 2016, Ian Lance Taylor <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> the users of the said packages can say: upgrade me to any version in the
> current major version range but don't give me the next version.
>
> @dlsniper <https://github.com/dlsniper> But the package is being moved. I
> don't see how changing the version helps when the final intent is that the
> package should go away entirely. The point of an alias is to allow a
> rolling transition to the new package.
>
> Also in the presented case, this refactoring can be easily automated to be
> send a PR against all users of x/net/context to use context from Go 1.7
> onward.
>
> @dlsniper <https://github.com/dlsniper> I think that this aspect that you
> are more or less waving away is the hard part. There are many users. You
> can find them all--you can't assume that they are all on Github, some of
> them are using private repositories.
